cheatsheetvideos.quote: David Got help for his Class M using our Cheat sheet!
Jose explains how the motorcycle cheat sheet helped him pass his written exam.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Avoid other road users' blind spots.
questions.answerB: Provide a good view of the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Provide a poor view of road hazards.
questions.answerD: Invite others to share your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should help you to see others and be seen by them. Avoid riding in another driver's blind spot for a long period of time.

questions.question: To swerve correctly:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerB: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.explanation: To execute a swerve, press the handgrip on the side of your desired turn. Press on the opposite handgrip to return to your original direction after you are clear of the hazard.

questions.question: A passenger on a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Mount the motorcycle before the engine starts.
questions.answerB: Mount the motorcycle after the engine starts.
questions.answerC: Sit as close to the rear of the motorcycle as possible.
questions.answerD: Hold onto the seat.
questions.explanation: Passengers should get on a motorcycle only after the engine has been started and the transmission is put in neutral. They should sit as far forward as possible without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle and should hold onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: When approaching an object or uneven surface that you cannot avoid, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure the motorcycle is leaning to one side.
questions.answerB: Speed up.
questions.answerC: Swerve quickly.
questions.answerD: Rise slightly off the seat to allow your legs to absorb the shock.
questions.explanation: If you cannot avoid riding over an obstacle or uneven surface, you should approach it at as close to a 90-degree angle as possible. Slow down as much as you can, make sure that your motorcycle is upright, and rise slightly off your seat so your knees can absorb some of the force of impact. Just before contact, roll on the throttle slightly to lighten the front end.

questions.question: Riding on the far side of a lane when following another vehicle:
questions.answerA: Is recommended because you will be seen easily.
questions.answerB: Is not recommended because drivers seldom use their side mirrors and may not see you.
questions.answerC: Is recommended because a passenger in the vehicle may tell the driver that you are there.
questions.answerD: Is illegal because you have to ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Most drivers do not look at their side mirrors as often as they look at their rearview mirror. Therefore, when following a car, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of the lane where you are most likely to be visible in the driver's rearview mirror.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a way to prevent a friend from driving while intoxicated?
questions.answerA: Arrange a safe ride home for them.
questions.answerB: Get them involved in activities to slow their drinking and keep them busy while they sober up.
questions.answerC: Make them wait 15 minutes after their last drink before driving.
questions.answerD: Get other friends involved in stopping your friend from driving.
questions.explanation: To prevent someone from drinking and driving, it is a good idea to arrange an alternative way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow the pace of their drinking, use any available excuse to keep them from leaving, and recruit friends to help apply peer pressure.

questions.question: When should your rearview mirror be adjusted?
questions.answerA: After starting the motorcycle
questions.answerB: Before starting the motorcycle
questions.answerC: During the ride
questions.answerD: At a traffic signal
questions.explanation: You should clean and adjust both mirrors before starting your motorcycle. Adjust your mirrors so you can see the lane behind you and as much as possible of the lane next to you.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle in the city, your attention should be:
questions.answerA: Focused at least one half block ahead of you.
questions.answerB: Focused about 10 feet ahead of you.
questions.answerC: Focused behind you.
questions.answerD: Less focused than when on a highway.
questions.explanation: When riding in a city, you should consistently scan the road at a distance that is between one half block and one full block ahead of your motorcycle. It is important to be aware of vehicles, pedestrians, bicycles, and other hazards commonly found in cities. Scanning the road ahead may allow you to react to hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: Before carrying a passenger in traffic for the first time, you should:
questions.answerA: Read books about carrying passengers.
questions.answerB: Practice riding on an empty road.
questions.answerC: Flash your lights so others can see you.
questions.answerD: Practice riding on the shoulder of a road.
questions.explanation: Before transporting a passenger or heavy load in traffic for the first time, practice riding on a quiet road to get used to how your motorcycle handles differently with the additional weight.

questions.question: Maximum straight-line braking is done by:
questions.answerA: Using the front brake, then the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Using the rear brake, then the front brake.
questions.answerC: Using the front and rear brakes at the same time without locking either wheel.
questions.answerD: Using the front and rear brakes at the same time while locking the rear wheel.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by simultaneously applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel.

questions.question: Studies show that nearly ______ of riders killed in motorcycle crashes had been drinking.
questions.answerA: 20 percent
questions.answerB: 40 percent
questions.answerC: 60 percent
questions.answerD: 80 percent
questions.explanation: Alcohol is a major contributor to motorcycle crashes, particularly fatal crashes. Studies show that nearly 40 percent of all riders killed in motorcycle accidents had been drinking.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates one alcoholic drink per hour. If a person consumed eight alcoholic drinks four hours ago, how many drinks likely remain in their body?
questions.answerA: One drink
questions.answerB: Two drinks
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: The minimum number of drinks left in a person's system can be estimated by subtracting the number of hours since the last drink from the total number of drinks consumed. In this case, the alcohol content of about four drinks would remain.

questions.question: When applying the front brake, you should:
questions.answerA: Apply the lever by squeezing firmly and progressively.
questions.answerB: Grab at the brake with only two fingers.
questions.answerC: Press down on the brake lever with your foot.
questions.answerD: Stomp on the brake lever.
questions.explanation: To apply the front brake, firmly and smoothly squeeze the brake lever with all four fingers, applying progressively more force.

questions.question: The center portion of a traffic lane is where:
questions.answerA: Debris and oil drippings from cars often collect.
questions.answerB: Motorcycle riders should always travel for safety.
questions.answerC: Most accidents happen.
questions.answerD: Drivers are least likely to see a motorcyclist.
questions.explanation: The centermost portion of a lane is where debris and oil drippings from cars often collect. Other hazards, such as utility hole covers, can also be found in the centermost portion of the lane.

questions.question: When riding through a curve, a group of motorcyclists should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a staggered formation.
questions.answerB: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in a side-by-side formation.
questions.answerD: Use both lanes if possible.
questions.explanation: While a staggered formation is generally recommended, riders in a group should move into a single-file formation when taking curves, taking turns, entering a highway, or leaving a highway.

questions.question: When you have mounted your motorcycle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Make sure the mirrors are clean.
questions.answerB: Make sure the horn works.
questions.answerC: Close the fuel supply valve.
questions.answerD: Make sure the clutch works smoothly.
questions.explanation: After mounting your motorcycle, you should make sure the clutch, throttle, horn, and brakes all work properly. Clean and adjust the mirrors and make sure that the fuel supply valve is open.

questions.question: Head and neck injuries can be reduced by:
questions.answerA: Wearing a helmet.
questions.answerB: Wearing a leather jacket.
questions.answerC: Using the rear brake only.
questions.answerD: Wearing goggles.
questions.explanation: The risk of head and neck injuries is greatly reduced by wearing a high-quality helmet. A helmet is a rider's best defense against injury in the case of an accident.

questions.question: If you are using an unfamiliar motorcycle, what should you do before riding?
questions.answerA: Ride like you would on your bike, since all bikes are about the same.
questions.answerB: Check the controls and shift pattern.
questions.answerC: Take the owner’s word that everything is in working order.
questions.answerD: Assume you know where all the controls are located.
questions.explanation: All motorcycles are slightly different, so you should check the controls and make sure you know the gear pattern before riding an unfamiliar motorcycle. Work the throttle, clutch, and brakes a few times prior to riding.

questions.question: Motorcycle headlights are:
questions.answerA: Usually more powerful than a car’s headlights.
questions.answerB: Usually just as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerC: Usually not as powerful as a car’s headlights.
questions.answerD: Usually larger than a car’s headlights.
questions.explanation: Motorcycle headlights are generally smaller and less powerful than those of cars.

questions.question: Proper clothing for riding offers all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Comfort.
questions.answerB: Protection in a collision.
questions.answerC: Protection from the cold.
questions.answerD: Discomfort.
questions.explanation: Proper clothing for riding can help protect you from injury in the event of a collision. It can also protect against routine hazards and discomforts, such as hot or cold weather.

questions.question: A proper lane position can help you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Avoid other drivers' blindspots.
questions.answerB: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Go faster.
questions.answerD: Set up for turns.
questions.explanation: Your lane position affects a number of factors that are important to your safety on the road. Among other things, your position should help you increase your ability to see and be seen, avoid other drivers' blind spots, and set you up for any turns you plan to make.

questions.question: When checking tires before a ride, you should look at all of the following except:
questions.answerA: Air pressure
questions.answerB: General wear
questions.answerC: General tread
questions.answerD: Shininess
questions.explanation: Before each ride, you should check the air pressure, tread, and general wear of your tires.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a type of protective riding gear?
questions.answerA: A leather jacket
questions.answerB: Boots that go above the ankle
questions.answerC: Hearing protection
questions.answerD: Pants made of a soft material
questions.explanation: Appropriate protective gear for motorcycling includes a jacket and pants made of leather or another sturdy material; footwear that covers and supports your ankles; and hearing protection, even if you wear a helmet.

questions.question: Moving into another lane while taking a curve is often the result of:
questions.answerA: Taking the turn too fast.
questions.answerB: Lanes that are too narrow.
questions.answerC: Not knowing how to steer.
questions.answerD: Lanes that are too wide.
questions.explanation: Trying to enter a curve or turn at a speed that is too fast for conditions may cause you to cross into another lane of traffic or leave the road entirely.

questions.question: An advantage to keeping a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles is that:
questions.answerA: You can pass danger more quickly.
questions.answerB: You will have a more narrow view of the road so you can stay focused.
questions.answerC: You will have more time to react to the movements of others.
questions.answerD: You can more easily follow the path of the next vehicle.
questions.explanation: Maintaining a cushion of space between your motorcycle and other vehicles on the road will give you a clearer view of any emerging hazards, more time to react to hazards, and more space to maneuver around them.

questions.question: When changing lanes, you should:
questions.answerA: Signal, use your mirrors, and turn your head.
questions.answerB: Signal and use your mirrors.
questions.answerC: Turn your head and change lanes.
questions.answerD: Signal and change lanes.
questions.explanation: Always use the proper turn signal before a turn or lane change. Use your mirrors and perform head checks before changing lanes to check for traffic surrounding your vehicle.

questions.question: If you must swerve, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerB: Turn your handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerD: Press the handgrip in the opposite direction of the turn.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: To adjust for added weight when riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Operate at a slower speed than usual.
questions.answerB: Maintain a shorter following distance that you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.answerC: Operate at a faster speed than usual.
questions.answerD: Brake a little later than you would if riding without a passenger.
questions.explanation: The extra weight of a passenger means that your motorcycle will need more time than usual to speed up, slow down, and turn. To accommodate the added weight, you should reduce your speed; start slowing earlier than normal; increase your following distance; and seek out larger gaps when crossing, entering, or merging with traffic.

questions.question: When riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a position that will allow the other driver to see you in their rearview mirror.
questions.answerB: Assume the driver sees you.
questions.answerC: Ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding behind a car, you should position yourself so you can be seen in the other driver's rearview mirror. Riding in the center portion of the lane will generally ensure that you will appear in the middle of their rearview mirror, where the driver is most likely to notice you.

questions.question: When you park a motorcycle next to a curb, it should be:
questions.answerA: Parked at a 90-degree angle with the rear wheel touching the curb.
questions.answerB: Parked at a 45-degree angle with the front tire touching the curb.
questions.answerC: Parked like a car, with the front and rear wheels the same distance from the curb.
questions.answerD: Parked at the left edge of the parking space so approaching drivers can more easily see the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: When parking a motorcycle next to a curb, you should create at a 90-degree angle with the curb by touching your rear wheel to the curb.

questions.question: When stopping behind a vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Stop far behind the vehicle, then slowly creep up.
questions.answerB: Stay well behind the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Make a quick stop right behind the vehicle.
questions.answerD: Stay about four car lengths behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: Stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even if you are both stopped. The vehicle could back up unexpectedly, or you may need space to get out of the way of another vehicle bearing down on you from behind.

questions.question: Your lane position should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Help you avoid road hazards.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerC: Help you avoid being seen by other drivers.
questions.answerD: Increase your ability to be seen by others.
questions.explanation: A well-chosen lane position should increase your ability to see and be seen and keep you out of other drivers' blind spots. It should help you avoid surface hazards, protect your lane from other drivers, communicate your intentions to others, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and offer you an escape route from any hazards that may arise.

questions.question: When may you not need to increase your following distance?
questions.answerA: When the road is slippery
questions.answerB: When there is a lot of traffic
questions.answerC: When you can see through the vehicle in front of you
questions.answerD: When it is raining
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a longer following distance.

questions.question: Which of the following provides the best protection?
questions.answerA: Sunglasses
questions.answerB: Windshield
questions.answerC: Goggles
questions.answerD: Face shield
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield provides protection for the wearer's entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles may protect someone's eyes, but not the rest of their face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: A shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Can protect a rider's face in a crash.
questions.answerB: Is only useful in protecting riders from dirt.
questions.answerC: Does not offer as much protection as goggles.
questions.answerD: Should not be used with a helmet.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can provide protection for your entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A face shield also provides routine protection from dirt, dust, insects, rain, and pebbles.

questions.question: When you ride, the best gear to wear is:
questions.answerA: Any gear that helps to protect you.
questions.answerB: The lowest-priced gear.
questions.answerC: Gear that looks good.
questions.answerD: Any gear that fits.
questions.explanation: You should wear gear that helps protect you while you ride. It is best to wear a DOT-approved helmet, face or eye protection, and protective clothing.

questions.question: When it is obvious that you are going to turn, you:
questions.answerA: Do not need to use a turn signal.
questions.answerB: Should still use a turn signal.
questions.answerC: Only need to use a turn signal if there are nearby pedestrians.
questions.answerD: Only need to use a turn signal if you are at a stop light.
questions.explanation: You must use proper turn signals every time you turn or change lanes, even if you think your intentions are obvious. Signals are always important, even if no one else seems to be around to see them. There may be other vehicles nearby that you can't see or haven't yet noticed.

questions.question: Use a turn signal:
questions.answerA: When you’re planning to increase your speed.
questions.answerB: Only when there is a lot of traffic.
questions.answerC: Any time you plan on changing lanes.
questions.answerD: Only if it is dark outside.
questions.explanation: You should use a turn signal every time you plan to turn or change lanes, even if you think no one else is around to see it.

questions.question: When deciding on a lane position, you should:
questions.answerA: Always ride in the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Always ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Be flexible and base your decision off of numerous factors.
questions.explanation: In general, there is no single best lane position. No portion of the lane need be avoided at all times. Position yourself in the portion of the lane where you are most likely to be seen and you can maintain a cushion of space around you.

questions.question: Clothing made of which type of material can offer the best protection to motorcyclists?
questions.answerA: Leather
questions.answerB: Wool
questions.answerC: Polyester
questions.answerD: Silk
questions.explanation: Leather garments can provide the greatest level of protection to motorcyclists. It is important to wear clothing that covers your legs and arms entirely when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: How do headache, cold, and hay fever medications usually affect your body?
questions.answerA: They make you drowsy.
questions.answerB: They make you more alert.
questions.answerC: They make you hungry.
questions.answerD: They make you unable to concentrate.
questions.explanation: Most drugs taken to ease headaches, colds, hay fever, allergies, or nerves can make the consumer drowsy and may impair their ability to ride safely. When taking a medication, it is important for a rider to know how the drug affects their body before riding.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerA: At high speeds.
questions.answerB: After riding for a long time.
questions.answerC: Far from home.
questions.answerD: On short trips.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on short trips that are less than five miles long at speeds slower than 30 miles per hour.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: When in traffic, motorcycles need:
questions.answerA: Much less distance to stop than cars.
questions.answerB: Less distance to stop than cars.
questions.answerC: As much distance to stop as cars.
questions.answerD: More distance to stop than cars.
questions.explanation: In traffic, a motorcycle needs as much distance to stop as a car does.

questions.question: In general, the body gets rid of almost ______ per hour.
questions.answerA: One drink
questions.answerB: Two drinks
questions.answerC: Three drinks
questions.answerD: Four drinks
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour.

questions.question: Why should a load be placed low on a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: If a load is too high, it raises the center of gravity.
questions.answerB: If a load is too high, it may interfere with the turn signals.
questions.answerC: It may be difficult to see over a load that is placed too high.
questions.answerD: Others can't see your load if it is low.
questions.explanation: Placing a load too high on a motorcycle will raise the motorcycle's center of gravity and risk upsetting its balance.

questions.question: When choosing clothes for riding, which of the following is not a good choice?
questions.answerA: A jacket and pants that cover your arms and legs completely
questions.answerB: Boots or shoes that cover your ankles
questions.answerC: Gloves made of leather
questions.answerD: A baseball cap to cover your hair
questions.explanation: To protect yourself against injury, you should wear a DOT-compliant helmet; face or eye protection; a jacket and long pants made of sturdy material; boots or shoes that are high and sturdy enough to cover and support your ankles; and gloves made of durable material.

questions.question: A motorcyclist can discourage other vehicles from lane sharing by:
questions.answerA: Riding in the left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: Riding in the center portion of a lane.
questions.answerC: Giving dirty looks if another driver moves into their lane.
questions.answerD: Riding in a zigzag pattern to fill up a lane.
questions.explanation: Any time a driver may be tempted to try to squeeze into your lane next to you, ride in the center portion of the lane to discourage them from doing so.

questions.question: A DOT-approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Restricts the wearer's vision to the sides.
questions.answerB: Can greatly reduce the severity of a head injury.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Makes it more difficult for the wearer to control their motorcycle.
questions.explanation: Wearing a helmet while riding greatly improves your chances of avoiding serious injury to your head or neck in the case of a crash. A DOT-approved helmet will not restrict your vision to the sides.

questions.question: When crossing railroad tracks that are parallel to the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Cross the tracks at a 90-degree angle.
questions.answerB: Avoid crossing the tracks for any reason.
questions.answerC: Try to cross the tracks at a 45-degree angle.
questions.answerD: Slowly inch across the tracks.
questions.explanation: To safely cross railroad tracks, trolley tracks, or pavement seams running parallel to your lane, move to a lane position that will allow you to cross them at an angle of at least 45 degrees. Then, make a quick, sharp turn. If you try to edge across, the tracks or seam could catch your tires and throw you off balance.

questions.question: A way to lower the risk of being involved in a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Communicate your intentions to other road users.
questions.answerB: Not look ahead while riding.
questions.answerC: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerD: Ride in the parts of a lane that make it difficult to be seen.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: In hot weather, wearing a riding jacket:
questions.answerA: Can help protect against heat exhaustion and dehydration.
questions.answerB: Is discouraged because it can cause heat-related problems.
questions.answerC: Should only be done if the jacket is a light color.
questions.answerD: Is not important.
questions.explanation: A riding jacket and long pants should still be worn when riding in hot weather. In addition to their other safety benefits, they can protect a rider from heat exhaustion and dehydration.

questions.question: Taking corners too fast:
questions.answerA: Can cause the rider to go into another lane.
questions.answerB: Is better than going too slowly.
questions.answerC: Often causes the rider to stay in their lane.
questions.answerD: Is acceptable because motorcycles are smaller than other types of vehicles.
questions.explanation: Taking a corner too fast may cause you to cross into another lane or go off the road. Be sure to decelerate before beginning to take a turn or curve.

questions.question: If the throttle is stuck, you should:
questions.answerA: Jump off the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Twist the throttle back and forth several times.
questions.answerD: Not try to twist the throttle.
questions.explanation: If your throttle becomes stuck, try twisting it back and forth several times. If this does not free your throttle, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time.

questions.question: To accommodate a passenger, you may have to:
questions.answerA: Adjust the shocks.
questions.answerB: Adjust the handlebars.
questions.answerC: Adjust the brakes.
questions.answerD: Adjust the throttle.
questions.explanation: Because of the extra weight placed on a motorcycle by a passenger, you may need to adjust the motorcycle's shocks before carrying a passenger. Because the motorcycle will sit at a different angle, you should also adjust the headlight and mirrors to compensate for the additional weight.

questions.question: Most motorcycle crashes happen:
questions.answerA: On short trips.
questions.answerB: On long trips.
questions.answerC: After at least an hour of riding.
questions.answerD: After more than 8 hours of riding.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes happen on trips shorter than five miles, just a few minutes after the rider starts out.

questions.question: If the road is wet, you should avoid:
questions.answerA: The left portion of a lane.
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: All areas of the lane.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars and trucks collect in a strip in the center portion of a lane. This strip usually still provides enough traction for motorcyclists to operate safely, except when the road is wet. The strip is usually narrow enough that you can ride to its side and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: In a normal turn:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle and rider should lean together.
questions.answerB: The motorcycle and rider should lean in opposite directions.
questions.answerC: The motorcycle should lean, but the rider should not.
questions.answerD: The rider should lean, but the motorcycle should not.
questions.explanation: During normal turns, the motorcycle and the rider should be leaning together at the same angle. In slow, tight turns, only the motorcycle should lean while the rider keeps their body straight up.

questions.question: When stopped behind another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close as possible to the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Maintain a space cushion between your motorcycle and the other vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not use your rearview mirrors to monitor traffic behind you.
questions.answerD: Look for opportunities to squeeze through the stopped traffic.
questions.explanation: You should stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even when you are both stopped. This will give you room to escape if the vehicle backs up unexpectedly or if another vehicle approaches too quickly from behind.

questions.question: Which of the following will help you ride safely on slippery surfaces?
questions.answerA: Using only the front brake
questions.answerB: Using both brakes
questions.answerC: Using the center lane
questions.answerD: Maintaining or increasing your speed
questions.explanation: When riding on slippery surfaces, reduce your speed, brake using both brakes, and avoid sudden moves. Avoid the center of the lane and instead follow tire tracks left by cars. Always keep an eye out for hazards that may make a road surface especially slippery, such as oil spots and loose gravel.

questions.question: A simple way to make your motorcycle easier to see is to:
questions.answerA: Ride with a large flag attached to its frame.
questions.answerB: Ride with the headlight turned on.
questions.answerC: Wave at other drivers.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder whenever possible.
questions.explanation: You can make yourself easier to see by wearing brightly-colored, reflective clothing. Ride with your headlight on at all times and use your turn signals and brake light appropriately.

questions.question: When passing parked vehicles, motorcycle riders should be especially cautious of:
questions.answerA: Motorists looking for a place to park.
questions.answerB: Cars leaving their parking spaces.
questions.answerC: Oncoming traffic.
questions.answerD: Noise.
questions.explanation: When passing parked vehicles, use caution. You may encounter vehicles pulling away from the curb or leaving parking spaces.

questions.question: You should choose the lane position that can:
questions.answerA: Minimize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerB: Maximize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerC: Maximize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow others to pass you.
questions.answerD: Minimize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow you to closely follow another vehicle.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise. Choose a lane position that maximizes your space cushion.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Be visible to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: To help provide space for drivers attempting to merge into your lane from an entrance ramp, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerB: Merge into the next lane, if possible.
questions.answerC: Not worry about it, since they are the ones trying to merge.
questions.answerD: Ride on the far left shoulder.
questions.explanation: Drivers merging onto a highway and into your lane may not notice your motorcycle. Give them plenty of space to safely merge by moving into a different lane, if you can.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerA: Lean as you lean.
questions.answerB: Hold onto the seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back on the seat as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: Passengers should lean as the operator leans. A passenger should sit as far forward as they can without crowding the operator and hold firmly onto the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: Mirror checks:
questions.answerA: Are unimportant.
questions.answerB: Should only be done on long trips.
questions.answerC: Should be part of your normal scanning routine.
questions.answerD: Are not helpful since you can’t do anything about what is behind you.
questions.explanation: Frequent mirror checks should be part of your normal searching routine. Additionally, make a special point of using your mirrors before changing lanes, when stopping at an intersection, and before slowing down.

questions.question: When riding in a group, motorcyclists:
questions.answerA: Do not need space cushions.
questions.answerB: Should increase their space cushions.
questions.answerC: Should reduce their usual space cushions by half.
questions.answerD: Should maintain adequate space cushions.
questions.explanation: When riding in a group, you should maintain close ranks but still keep an adequate space cushion around each rider.

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered protective clothing for a motorcyclist?
questions.answerA: A jacket
questions.answerB: Boots
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: A stocking cap
questions.explanation: You should wear appropriate protective clothing when riding. Protective garments include sturdy pants and jackets that entirely cover your arms and legs, boots or heavy shoes that cover and support your ankles, and sturdy gloves.

questions.question: If your motorcycle begins to weave while you are riding over rain grooves or bridge gratings, you should:
questions.answerA: Relax, maintain a steady speed, and ride straight across the surface.
questions.answerB: Tighten your hold on the handle grips and increase your speed to get past the hazard.
questions.answerC: Travel in a zigzag motion.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder instead of on the grooves.
questions.explanation: The weaving motion that occurs when a motorcycle rides over rain grooves or bridge gratings is generally not dangerous. If you experience weaving when riding over one of these surfaces, simply relax and proceed straight across the grooves or gratings at a steady speed. Trying to compensate for the weaving motion by zigzagging is more dangerous than riding straight.

questions.question: A motorcyclist should:
questions.answerA: Pick a favorite portion of the lane and stay in that portion all the time.
questions.answerB: Continually weave among the lane positions to keep other drivers out of their lane.
questions.answerC: Choose a lane position based on road and traffic conditions.
questions.answerD: Not worry about lane position.
questions.explanation: There is no one lane position that is always best and no one lane position that should always be avoided. Adjust your lane position in response to changes in road and traffic conditions.

questions.question: It is most important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: Switching into a neutral gear.
questions.answerB: You will be slowing suddenly.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals are not working.
questions.explanation: If a tailgater is following you too closely, it is advisable to flash your brake light before you begin to decelerate. The tailgater may be concentrating on you and may not be aware of hazards farther down the road that you are slowing to avoid.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Use the rear brake firmly while gradually increasing the braking pressure of the front brake.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: If road conditions require a longer stopping distance than normal, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your usual following distance.
questions.answerB: Increase your usual following distance.
questions.answerC: Travel on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Ask someone else to operate your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a minimum three-second following distance.

questions.question: When approaching a blind intersection with a stop sign, riders should:
questions.answerA: Stop at the stop sign then proceed through the intersection.
questions.answerB: Ignore the stop sign and move forward to get a better look.
questions.answerC: Stop at the stop sign before moving forward to improve their view of cross traffic.
questions.answerD: Proceed through the intersection without stopping.
questions.explanation: When approaching a blind intersection that is controlled by a stop line or stop sign, you must first stop where indicated. You may then edge forward and stop again just short of where the cross traffic lane meets your lane. From that position, lean your body forward and look around buildings, parked cars, or bushes to see if anything is approaching. Make sure your front wheel stays out of the crossroad while you are looking.

questions.question: If you are not traveling slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, what could happen?
questions.answerA: Your motorcycle may lurch and the rear tire may skid.
questions.answerB: The horn may go off.
questions.answerC: Your motorcycle may lurch and the front tire may skid.
questions.answerD: Your motorcycle may lurch and a warning light will go on.
questions.explanation: If you are not riding slowly enough when shifting into a lower gear, your motorcycle may lurch and the rear tire may skid, causing you to lose control of your motorcycle. Be sure that you are moving slowly enough before shifting into a lower gear.

questions.question: If a friend has been drinking and wants to ride their motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Let them.
questions.answerB: Encourage them to take less-crowded roads.
questions.answerC: Push their bike over.
questions.answerD: Encourage friends to talk them out of riding.
questions.explanation: Never let someone ride if they have had too much to drink. Do whatever you can to prevent them from riding. It can be helpful to recruit a group of friends to intervene and apply peer pressure to the person.

questions.question: A passenger should never:
questions.answerA: Wear a helmet.
questions.answerB: Lean when the operator leans.
questions.answerC: Wear clothing that is tight.
questions.answerD: Ride sidesaddle.
questions.explanation: In South Carolina, passengers under the age of 21 must wear a helmet and eye protection, though it is recommended that all motorcycle riders wear helmets and eye protection. Passengers should avoid wearing loose clothing that might catch on the motorcycle and should always lean with the operator when turning. Passengers should never be allowed to ride sidesaddle.

questions.question: When riding, the best sitting position:
questions.answerA: Requires your arms be used to hold you up.
questions.answerB: Allows you to easily reach the controls.
questions.answerC: Keeps your arms straight when reaching the handle grips.
questions.answerD: Keeps your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be seated in a posture that allows you to use your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. You should not have to stretch to reach the handgrips and your arms should be slightly bent when holding them. You should keep your knees against the gas tank to maintain your balance.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the motorcycle is as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Assume other drivers can’t see you.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with taking steps to ensure that other drivers see you.
questions.answerD: Ride offensively.
questions.explanation: Because motorcycles are small in stature and have fewer and smaller lights than other vehicles, they can be difficult to see. For your safety, it is best to ride defensively and assume that others on the road do not see you.

questions.question: When preparing to pass another vehicle, you should ride in the left portion of your lane because:
questions.answerA: It increases your line of sight.
questions.answerB: It decreases your line of sight.
questions.answerC: It makes it difficult to see beyond the vehicle.
questions.answerD: It allows the other driver to speed up.
questions.explanation: When preparing to pass on the left, you should ride in the left portion of your lane, both to increase your line of sight and to make yourself more visible to drivers already in the passing lane.

questions.question: If your front wheel skids as a result of braking, you should:
questions.answerA: Keep the front brake engaged.
questions.answerB: Release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.
questions.answerC: Release the front brake and only use the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Release both brakes and coast to a stop.
questions.explanation: If your front wheel locks as a result of braking, you should release the front brake immediately and re-apply the brake smoothly.

questions.question: When should the front brake be used?
questions.answerA: Any time the rider is slowing or stopping
questions.answerB: Only when slowing or stopping on slippery roads
questions.answerC: Only when slowing or stopping in an emergency
questions.answerD: Only when slowing or stopping in traffic
questions.explanation: A rider should always use both brakes every time they slow or stop.

questions.question: You have been drinking alcohol. If you wait an hour for each drink before riding your motorcycle:
questions.answerA: You cannot be arrested for drinking and riding.
questions.answerB: Your riding skills will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Side effects from the drinking may still remain.
questions.answerD: You will be okay as long as you ride slowly.
questions.explanation: On average, the body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. However, some alcohol may accumulate in the body even if a person consumes only one drink per hour. Their abilities and judgment can still be impaired.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger or cargo:
questions.answerA: It may take less time to accelerate, but more time to stop.
questions.answerB: It may take more time to accelerate and stop.
questions.answerC: It may take more time to accelerate, but less time to stop.
questions.answerD: It may take less time to accelerate and stop.
questions.explanation: Because of the additional weight added by cargo or a passenger, motorcycles may take longer to accelerate and stop than they would if only transporting the operator.

questions.question: To stop quickly, it is best to:
questions.answerA: Throttle down and use the front brake.
questions.answerB: Use the rear brake only.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake only.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: If someone is tailgating you, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride faster to shake them.
questions.answerB: Alert the local police.
questions.answerC: Ride on the shoulder of the road.
questions.answerD: Allow them to pass.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to let them get in front of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let the tailgater pass. Riding faster may only increase the danger by prompting them to continue tailgating you at the higher speed.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger on a motorcycle, you must:
questions.answerA: Have a seat that is large enough for two riders.
questions.answerB: Only have one set of footrests.
questions.answerC: Not encourage the passenger to wear protective clothing.
questions.answerD: Put a sticker on the brake light to warn other motorists that a passenger is on the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: You should not carry a passenger unless your motorcycle has a seat that is large enough for two riders. The motorcycle should be equipped with footrests for the passenger. Your passenger should wear the same kind of protective gear that is recommended to operators.

questions.question: As an operator, you should prepare a passenger to ride by instructing them to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as possible.
questions.answerC: Maintain a large space between themselves and you.
questions.answerD: Keep their legs away from the muffler and chains.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a ride, you should ask your passenger to mount the motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding you and hold onto the motorcycle's passenger handholds or onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep their legs away from the muffler, chains, and other moving parts.

questions.question: An approved helmet:
questions.answerA: Allows the wearer to see as far to the sides as necessary.
questions.answerB: Restricts the field of vision.
questions.answerC: Is usually uncomfortable.
questions.answerD: Does not have any markings or tags.
questions.explanation: Any approved helmet will allow a rider to see as far to the sides as is necessary for safe riding. Approved helmets will have labels and markings providing the manufacturer's name, relevant information and instructions, and information about the standards the helmet meets.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerA: Slow or stop
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is bent at the elbow and pointing upward, it means the operator plans to turn right or change lanes to the right.

questions.question: When being passed, do not move into the portion of the lane farthest from the passing vehicle because:
questions.answerA: The passing vehicle may re-enter your lane too early.
questions.answerB: You may prevent another vehicle from passing you.
questions.answerC: The portion of the lane nearest the passing vehicle is better.
questions.answerD: You are more likely to experience a wind blast from the passing vehicle on the far side of the lane.
questions.explanation: When being passed, you should not ride on the side of your lane that is farthest from the passing vehicle. Doing so may tempt the driver to return to your lane before there is actually room for them to do so safely.

questions.question: Your motorcycle’s brake light is:
questions.answerA: More noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerB: Less noticeable than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerC: Less important than a car’s brake lights.
questions.answerD: More easily seen than a car’s brake lights.
questions.explanation: The brake light of a motorcycle is usually not as noticeable as the brake lights of a car. Flashing your brake light before slowing or stopping can help other drivers notice that you are about to brake.

questions.question: When selecting a helmet, make sure it is all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Designed to meet U.S. Department of Transportation standards.
questions.answerB: Snug.
questions.answerC: Defect-free.
questions.answerD: Attractive.
questions.explanation: You should select a helmet that meets U.S. Department of Transportation and state standards; fits snugly all the way around; and has no obvious defects, such as cracks, loose padding, or frayed straps.

questions.question: A wobble, or shaking of the front wheel and handlebars, may be caused by:
questions.answerA: Incorrect tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Brakes that are not working properly.
questions.answerC: A balanced load.
questions.answerD: Excessive wind.
questions.explanation: Most wobbles are caused by improper loading of the motorcycle, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure.

questions.question: To lower the chance of a crash, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Be visible.
questions.answerB: Communicate your intentions.
questions.answerC: Be prepared to react to hazards.
questions.answerD: Hope another driver sees you.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you must ensure that you are visible to others on the road and that other drivers understand what you're planning to do. Clearly communicate your intentions through proper signaling and lane positioning. Maintain an adequate space cushion and scan your path of travel, identifying upcoming hazards and being prepared to react.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Protect your lane from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Allow you a nice view of scenery.
questions.answerC: Place you in other drivers’ blind spots.
questions.answerD: Hide your intentions from other drivers.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely only on the front brake.
questions.answerB: Rely only on the rear brake.
questions.answerC: Use the front brake and then the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: If you need to stop quickly, you should apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: The proper clothing for riding a motorcycle should:
questions.answerA: Cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Cover your arms completely, but leave your legs exposed.
questions.answerC: Cover your legs completely, but leave your arms exposed.
questions.answerD: Be whatever makes you most comfortable, regardless of safety.
questions.explanation: To be adequately protected while riding, you should wear a jacket and pants that completely cover your arms and legs.

questions.question: All of the following will lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, except:
questions.answerA: Remaining alert.
questions.answerB: Identifying hazards and prioritizing risks.
questions.answerC: Riding without a headlight.
questions.answerD: Maintaining a space cushion.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you should remain alert and ready to react to any hazard. Identify hazards and decide the order in which you need to address the hazards. Always use your headlight to make yourself more visible and maintain an adequate space cushion around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: If taking a long trip, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to minimize the number of rest breaks.
questions.answerB: Use artificial stimulants, like caffeine, if you feel drowsy.
questions.answerC: Dress warmly to avoid getting too cold during the ride.
questions.answerD: Schedule more than 12 hours of riding a day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of fatigue on a long trip, dress to protect yourself from tiring elements, such as wind, cold, and rain. Limit yourself to no more than six hours of riding per day and take rest brakes at least every two hours. Avoid using artificial stimulants, as these only result in extreme fatigue when they wear off.

questions.question: Riders who do not wear helmets while riding are ________ to die in a crash than riders who do wear helmets.
questions.answerA: Half as likely
questions.answerB: Twice as likely
questions.answerC: Three times as likely
questions.answerD: Just as likely
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: What is the best lane position for a motorcycle?
questions.answerA: The left position
questions.answerB: The center position
questions.answerC: The right position
questions.answerD: There is no single best lane position.
questions.explanation: No single lane position is always best and no single lane position should always be avoided. Adjust your lane position as road and traffic conditions change, choosing a position that will maximize your space cushion and allow other drivers to see you more easily.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerA: Two times
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers see you, especially if they make eye contact.
questions.answerB: Never assume other drivers see you.
questions.answerC: Stay focused on moving through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Speed up to make others notice you.
questions.explanation: Never assume that other drivers see you, even if they make eye contact with you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to notice them. Always reduce your speed when approaching an intersection.

questions.question: As you slow or stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift up through the gears.
questions.answerB: Shift down through the gears.
questions.answerC: Take the bike out of gear.
questions.answerD: Stay in the same gear.
questions.explanation: You should shift down through the gears with the clutch as you slow or stop. Stay in first gear while you are stopped so you can move quickly, if needed.

questions.question: Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) are designed to:
questions.answerA: Prevent skidding and wheel lock-up.
questions.answerB: Prevent brakes from activating if the roadway is dry.
questions.answerC: Apply brakes automatically.
questions.answerD: Warn you when your brake pad needs replacing.
questions.explanation: Some motorcycles are equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS). ABS is designed to prevent skidding and wheel lock-up when motorcyclists are stopping in straight-line, panic situations. ABS operates when maximum pressure is applied to both the front and rear brake controls. If electronic sensors detect the possibility of a wheel lock, brake hydraulic pressure is released then re-applied to maintain maximum braking effectiveness.

questions.question: Which of the following will best protect your eyes from wind?
questions.answerA: Eyeglasses
questions.answerB: Sunglasses
questions.answerC: A windshield
questions.answerD: Goggles
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields will help protect your eyes from wind. Most windshields, as well as eyeglasses or sunglasses, will not.

questions.question: Massachusetts law requires motorcycle riders to use headlights:
questions.answerA: One half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise.
questions.answerB: Whenever they want to.
questions.answerC: When it seems dark enough to use them.
questions.answerD: Only when traveling near other motorists.
questions.explanation: Massachusetts law requires motorcyclists to use their headlights from one half hour after sunset until one half hour before sunrise. It is safest to use headlights any time you are traveling by motorcycle.

questions.question: Your lane position should:
questions.answerA: Keep your intentions hidden from other drivers.
questions.answerB: Encourage other drivers to share your lane.
questions.answerC: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerD: Be close to the road signs.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: When riding with a passenger, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before.
questions.answerB: Not assume the passenger has traveled by motorcycle before and explain the process.
questions.answerC: Not let them ask questions.
questions.answerD: Not bother with explaining anything since they are only a passenger and not in control of the motorcycle.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle passenger needs to understand how to ensure a safe ride ride for both themselves and the operator. An operator should never assume the passenger already knows what to do. Give a passenger complete instructions before every ride.

questions.question: When going through a curve, you should:
questions.answerA: Always stay in the same portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerB: Always stay in the left portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerC: Always stay in the right portion of the lane throughout the entire curve.
questions.answerD: Remember that the best path may not follow the curve of the road.
questions.explanation: Road and traffic conditions can change at any time. Always be prepared to change your lane position as appropriate no matter where you are on a roadway. The best path through a curve does not necessarily follow the curve of the road.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection usually takes:
questions.answerA: A few minutes and should be done no more than once a month.
questions.answerB: A few minutes and should be done before every ride.
questions.answerC: Over an hour and should be performed by a mechanic.
questions.answerD: Over an hour and must only be done if you will be carrying a passenger.
questions.explanation: Conduct a thorough pre-ride inspection before every ride. It should usually take only a few minutes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a piece of protective clothing for a motorcycle rider?
questions.answerA: Jacket
questions.answerB: Boots
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: Sandals
questions.explanation: When riding, it is safest for a motorcyclist to wear a helmet, eye protection, a jacket, long pants, sturdy boots, and gloves.

questions.question: When changing lanes:
questions.answerA: There is no need to do a head check if you use your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Mirrors provide a full view of the road around your motorcycle.
questions.answerC: You should turn your head and look over your shoulder.
questions.answerD: You can assume drivers will properly respond to your turn signal.
questions.explanation: Motorcycles have blind spots just like any other vehicle. Always turn your head and look over your shoulder to check for traffic in your blind spot before changing lanes.

questions.question: Which vest or jacket color would best help you to be seen?
questions.answerA: Red
questions.answerB: Black
questions.answerC: Silver
questions.answerD: Blue
questions.explanation: Wearing brightly-colored clothing while riding will increase your chances of being seen. Bright oranges, yellows, reds, or greens are best and are preferable to drab or dark colors.

questions.question: When riding over rough surfaces, you should:
questions.answerA: Hold the handgrips loosely to allow for movement.
questions.answerB: Hold the handgrips firmly to maintain control.
questions.answerC: Use lots of throttle to help you get over the rough surface.
questions.answerD: Ride without a helmet as the helmet could become loose and cover your face.
questions.explanation: When riding over a rough surface, hold onto the handgrips firmly to ensure that you will maintain directional control over your motorcycle.

questions.question: It is important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: Approaching a police officer.
questions.answerB: Someone is following too closely.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals are not working.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to flash your brake light before slowing if someone is following you too closely. The other driver may be focused on you and be unaware of the upcoming hazard that is causing you to slow down. It is also important to flash your brake light if you are about to slow down in a place where other drivers might not expect you to do so.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: The front and rear brakes provide equal braking power.
questions.answerB: The front brake provides more braking power than the rear brake.
questions.answerC: The rear brake provides more braking power than the front brake.
questions.answerD: Only the front brake should be used when braking.
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear one, providing at least 70 percent of the total stopping power. Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop.

questions.question: Signals on a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: Serve little purpose since motorcycles are smaller than most other vehicles.
questions.answerB: Are very important to alert other motorists to a rider's intentions.
questions.answerC: Should not be used if no vehicles are close to the motorcycle.
questions.answerD: Are more complicated than those on a car.
questions.explanation: You are especially vulnerable as a motorcyclist, so it is very important to use your turn signals to alert others to your intentions. Always use them any time that you plan to change lanes or turn, even if you don't think anyone else is nearby.

questions.question: Fatigue can be increased by:
questions.answerA: Stopping frequently.
questions.answerB: Riding in cool weather.
questions.answerC: Being comfortable during your ride.
questions.answerD: Starting a ride late in the day.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: When consumed together, the effects of alcohol and drugs:
questions.answerA: Can be more pronounced than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerB: Are less dangerous than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerC: Are usually minimal.
questions.answerD: Often balance out.
questions.explanation: Many drugs, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, can impair your ability to ride safely. Some medications become even more dangerous when combined with alcohol.

questions.question: When riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your head and shoulders to look through turns.
questions.answerB: Keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Turn just your head and eyes to look through turns.
questions.explanation: When making a turn, you should look through the turn to where you want to go. Turn just your head, not your shoulders, and keep your eyes level with the horizon.

questions.question: For the best protection, jackets and pants:
questions.answerA: Should cover your arms and legs completely.
questions.answerB: Should be loose and flap in the wind while you are riding.
questions.answerC: Should only partially cover your arms and legs.
questions.answerD: Should be made of wool.
questions.explanation: To provide adequate protection when riding, jackets and pants should cover your arms and legs completely. Your clothing should fit snugly but be loose enough to let you move freely. Leather or newer kinds of synthetic materials provide the best protection in the case of an accident.

questions.question: Maximum front-line braking is accomplished by:
questions.answerA: Using the rear brake only.
questions.answerB: Using the front brake only.
questions.answerC: Using both brakes.
questions.answerD: Using the rear brake while downshifting.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by fully applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel. You should always use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator:
questions.answerA: Plans to turn left.
questions.answerB: Is about to stop.
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: Studies show that when motorcycles have their headlights turned on during the day:
questions.answerA: They are not as easy to see as other vehicles.
questions.answerB: They are more visible to other drivers than when their headlights are turned off.
questions.answerC: Other drivers are often confused.
questions.answerD: They are less safe than when their headlights are turned off.
questions.explanation: The best way to help other drivers see your motorcycle is to keep your headlight on whenever you ride. During the day, a motorcycle with its headlight on is twice as likely to be noticed.

questions.question: To swerve correctly, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift your weight quickly.
questions.answerB: Turn the handlebars quickly.
questions.answerC: Press the handle grip in the direction you plan to swerve.
questions.answerD: Press the handle grip in the direction opposite of where you plan to swerve.
questions.explanation: If you must swerve to avoid a hazard, apply a small amount of pressure to the appropriate handle grip. To swerve to the left, press the left handle grip, then press the right to recover. To swerve to the right, press the right handle grip, then the left.

questions.question: Which portion of the lane should be avoided?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: No portion of the lane should always be avoided.
questions.explanation: There is no lane position that is always best and no lane position that should always be avoided. Select a lane position that is appropriate for riding conditions.

questions.question: Maintain an adequate following distance behind other vehicles:
questions.answerA: To allow you time and space to identify and react to hazards.
questions.answerB: So you can tailgate.
questions.answerC: To allow for traffic counters to accurately count you as a vehicle.
questions.answerD: To encourage other drivers to cut you off.
questions.explanation: Maintaining an adequate following distance ensures that you will have enough space to stop or swerve out of the way if the vehicle ahead of you stops suddenly. A space cushion also provides you with a better view of any hazards on the road surface, such as potholes.

questions.question: You can increase your visibility by:
questions.answerA: Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Not using your turn signal.
questions.answerC: Wearing dark clothing.
questions.answerD: Waving at people.
questions.explanation: To increase your visibility, you can wear clothing that is brightly-colored or that contains reflective materials. Adding auxiliary lights to your motorcycle, using your turn signals, and flashing your brake light when appropriate are also good ways to get the attention of other road users.

questions.question: Which formation is best for a group of riders entering a curve?
questions.answerA: Pyramid
questions.answerB: Staggered
questions.answerC: Single-file
questions.answerD: Compressed
questions.explanation: A staggered formation is generally the best way for a group to maintain close ranks while also allowing each rider to maintain an adequate cushion of space. A single-file formation is preferable when taking curves, turning, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Avoid sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Brake quickly.
questions.explanation: To safely ride on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed, avoid making sudden movements, and use both brakes if you need to brake.

questions.question: What does this hand signal mean?
questions.answerA: Slow or stop
questions.answerB: Left turn
questions.answerC: Right turn
questions.answerD: Backing up
questions.explanation: Instead of or in addition to mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: During acceleration, a sidecar attached to a motorcycle will:
questions.answerA: Feel like it is lagging behind.
questions.answerB: Feel like it is accelerating faster than the motorcycle.
questions.answerC: Vibrate uncontrollably.
questions.answerD: Make acceleration seem faster.
questions.explanation: A sidecar is essentially an unpowered mass attached to the side of your motorcycle. Due to its inertia, it will feel like it is lagging behind when you accelerate.

questions.question: When a vehicle attempts to pass you from behind, you should:
questions.answerA: Move to the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Move to the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Move to the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about which portion of the lane you are using.
questions.explanation: When being passed, it is generally best to ride in the center portion of your lane. Being too close to the passing vehicle increases the risk of a collision.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Should only be used when you need to stop quickly.
questions.answerB: Should be used only under slippery conditions.
questions.answerC: Is not as effective as the rear brake.
questions.answerD: Is safe to use, if used properly.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes any time you slow or stop. It is safe to use the front brake, which is more powerful than the rear brake, as long as you use it properly.

questions.question: Goggles can:
questions.answerA: Protect your eyes and your face.
questions.answerB: Protect your face but not your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protect your eyes, but not your face.
questions.answerD: Not protect your face or eyes.
questions.explanation: Goggles can protect your eyes, but only a face shield can protect your entire face in a crash.

questions.question: When it is raining, it is usually best to:
questions.answerA: Ride in the center of the lane.
questions.answerB: Pull off to the side of the road until the rain stops.
questions.answerC: Ride in the tire tracks left by cars.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed.
questions.explanation: Wet pavement is especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Deposits of oil left by cars will not yet have washed off the roadway. If it is raining, it is safest to ride in the tire tracks left by cars. The left tire track will often be your best choice, although this may vary.

questions.question: Reflective clothing should:
questions.answerA: Never be worn.
questions.answerB: Be worn only during the day.
questions.answerC: Be worn only at night.
questions.answerD: Be worn day and night.
questions.explanation: Most motorcycle crashes occur in broad daylight. Increasing your visibility by wearing bright colors and reflective materials is a good idea at all times.

questions.question: To reduce your reaction time, you should:
questions.answerA: Ride under the speed limit.
questions.answerB: Cover the clutch and brakes.
questions.answerC: Shift into neutral when slowing.
questions.answerD: Accelerate before turning.
questions.explanation: When approaching a potentially dangerous area, such as an intersection, you should cover the clutch lever and both brakes in order to reduce the amount of time you will need to react to any hazards.

questions.question: If either tire goes flat while riding, you should:
questions.answerA: Roll on the throttle.
questions.answerB: Hold the handle grips loosely.
questions.answerC: Gently apply the brake of the non-flat tire.
questions.answerD: Increase your speed to exit the road more quickly.
questions.explanation: If one of your tires goes flat while you are riding, you should ease off the throttle and maintain a straight course as you slow down. If you must brake, gradually apply the brake of the tire that is not flat, if you are certain of which tire that is.

questions.question: Without a helmet, a motorcycle rider is ________ more likely to suffer a critical head injury in a crash.
questions.answerA: Three times
questions.answerB: Four times
questions.answerC: Five times
questions.answerD: Six times
questions.explanation: Without a helmet, a rider is five times more likely to sustain a critical head injury in a crash.

questions.question: To lean the motorcycle for a turn, you should:
questions.answerA: Press the handgrip in the direction of the turn.
questions.answerB: Press the handgrip in the direction opposite of the turn.
questions.answerC: Apply the front brake.
questions.answerD: Apply the rear brake.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle needs to lean in order to turn. To make this happen, press on the handgrip in the direction you want to turn.

questions.question: In the context of group riding, what does the hand signal pictured mean?
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Danger ahead.
questions.answerC: Stop.
questions.answerD: Merge.
questions.explanation: Hand signals are an important part of communication when riding in groups. If a lead rider extends their left arm straight down with their palm facing back, the group of riders should come to a stop.

questions.question: A linked braking system:
questions.answerA: Connects the front and rear brakes, applying both brakes when either brake lever is applied.
questions.answerB: Connects the front brake to the gear shifter, applying the brake when the rider downshifts.
questions.answerC: Connects the rear brake to a foot control.
questions.answerD: Connects the rear brake to a switch on the handlebar.
questions.explanation: A linked braking system connects the front and rear brakes on a motorcycle. This system applies braking pressure to both brakes when either the front or rear lever is used. Check your owner's manual for a detailed explanation of the braking system on your motorcycle.

questions.question: More than half of all crashes:
questions.answerA: Occur at speeds greater than 35 mph.
questions.answerB: Are caused by worn tires.
questions.answerC: Happen in the dark.
questions.answerD: Involve riders who have little experience on their motorcycles.
