questions.explanation: Any time a driver may be tempted to try to squeeze into your lane next to you, ride in the center portion of the lane to discourage them from doing so.

questions.question: When an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator:
questions.answerA: Plans to turn left.
questions.answerB: Is about to stop.
questions.answerC: Plans to turn right.
questions.answerD: Is about to slow down.
questions.explanation: Instead of mechanical turn signals, operators may use hand signals to indicate turns or stops. If an operator's left arm is extended straight out to the left, it means the operator plans to turn left or change lanes to the left.

questions.question: When riding, the best protection for an operator is:
questions.answerA: A cushion of space between their vehicle and other vehicles.
questions.answerB: A good leather jacket.
questions.answerC: Sturdy boots.
questions.answerD: A good understanding of motorcycle laws.
questions.explanation: Your first and best protection against collisions with other vehicles is simply to keep your distance from them. The only way to be sure you will have enough time to react to mistakes made by other drivers is to leave plenty of space between you and the vehicles around you. Wearing proper gear is also important when riding a motorcycle.

questions.question: The front brake supplies how much of a motorcycle's stopping power?
questions.answerA: About one-quarter
questions.answerB: About one-half
questions.answerC: About three-quarters
questions.answerD: All the stopping power
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It can provide three-fourths of the bike's total stopping power.

questions.question: Maximum straight-line braking is done by:
questions.answerA: Using the front brake, then the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Using the rear brake, then the front brake.
questions.answerC: Using the front and rear brakes at the same time without locking either wheel.
questions.answerD: Using the front and rear brakes at the same time while locking the rear wheel.
questions.explanation: Maximum straight-line braking is accomplished by simultaneously applying both the front and rear brakes without locking either wheel.

questions.question: When stopping:
questions.answerA: The rear brake should be applied first.
questions.answerB: The front brake should be applied first.
questions.answerC: Both brakes should be applied at the same time.
questions.answerD: Only one brake, front or rear, should be used.
questions.explanation: You should use both brakes every time you slow down or stop. Always apply the brakes simultaneously.

questions.question: Passing and being passed when riding a motorcycle is not much different than when driving a car. However:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle's visibility is more critical than that of a car.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle's visibility is not as important as that of a car.
questions.answerC: Passing should be done on the shoulder instead of on the main roadway.
questions.answerD: It is critical to make eye contact with the other driver when riding a motorcycle.
questions.explanation: While the basic techniques for safely passing and being passed are the same as when driving a car, visibility is more critical when riding a motorcycle. The smaller size of a motorcycle makes it easier for you to disappear into another vehicle's blind spot, or for the driver to fail to notice you even if they are able to see you.

questions.question: A shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Can protect a rider's face in a crash.
questions.answerB: Is only useful in protecting riders from dirt.
questions.answerC: Does not offer as much protection as goggles.
questions.answerD: Should not be used with a helmet.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can provide protection for your entire face in the event of a crash. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A face shield also provides routine protection from dirt, dust, insects, rain, and pebbles.

questions.question: Before every ride, it is important to check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The spokes.
questions.answerB: The tire tread.
questions.answerC: The lights.
questions.answerD: The seat fabric.
questions.explanation: Before every ride, you should complete a thorough check of your motorcycle. Be sure to check the rims and spokes to make sure none are bent, loose, or damaged; the condition and tread of the tires; and all of the lights.

questions.question: When is it important for a rider to use their mirrors?
questions.answerA: When slowing down or stopping suddenly
questions.answerB: When stopped at an intersection
questions.answerC: When changing lanes
questions.answerD: All of the above.
questions.explanation: It is particularly important for a rider to check their mirrors when slowing down or stopping, when stopped at an intersection, when changing lanes, and when turning.

questions.question: Before mounting a motorcycle, you should check all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The air pressure in the tires.
questions.answerB: Fluid levels.
questions.answerC: The turn signals.
questions.answerD: Damage to the paint.
questions.explanation: Before getting on a motorcycle, you should check the tread and air pressure of the tires, the oil and fluid levels, the lights, and the signals.

questions.question: Which of the following is not considered protective clothing for a motorcyclist?
questions.answerA: A jacket
questions.answerB: Boots
questions.answerC: Gloves
questions.answerD: A stocking cap
questions.explanation: You should wear appropriate protective clothing when riding. Protective garments include sturdy pants and jackets that entirely cover your arms and legs, boots or heavy shoes that cover and support your ankles, and sturdy gloves.

questions.question: The single most important thing you can do to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to:
questions.answerA: Wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.
questions.answerB: Wear shorts.
questions.answerC: Wear sneakers.
questions.answerD: Wear goggles.
questions.explanation: The single most effective action you can take to improve your chances of surviving a crash is to wear a high-quality helmet that is securely fastened.

questions.question: The primary source of information about your motorcycle should come from:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle's former owner.
questions.answerB: The owner’s manual.
questions.answerC: A library book about motorcycles.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle enthusiast.
questions.explanation: The owner's manual should be your primary source of information about your specific type of motorcycle. Be sure to read the manual before operating your motorcycle for the first time.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Not use your turn signals when changing lanes.
questions.answerB: Follow other vehicles closely.
questions.answerC: Watch about five feet ahead of your motorcycle while riding.
questions.answerD: Always be ready to use crash-avoidance techniques.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle. Always be ready to avoid an unexpected hazard.

questions.question: Before mounting your motorcycle, perform all of the following checks, except:
questions.answerA: Making sure the headlight works.
questions.answerB: Checking the oil level.
questions.answerC: Trying both brake controls to ensure the brake light activates.
questions.answerD: Ensuring that the paint is not scratched.
questions.explanation: Before riding, you should check the pressure and condition of your tires; check the oil and fluid levels; and make sure that the low beam headlight, high beam headlight, taillight, signal lights, and brake light all work properly.

questions.question: Your lane position should not:
questions.answerA: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerB: Help you avoid surface hazards.
questions.answerC: Provide you with an escape route.
questions.answerD: Welcome other drivers into your lane.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position can optimize a number of safety factors. Your lane position should keep you out of other vehicles’ blind spots, increase your ability to see and be seen, help you avoid surface hazards, help you avoid wind blasts from other vehicles, and provide you with an escape route from any hazards that might arise. You should be positioned in a way that discourages other drivers from trying to share your lane.

questions.question: When riding, a cushion of space is helpful to:
questions.answerA: Give you space to react to hazards.
questions.answerB: Hide you from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Prevent you from avoiding hazards.
questions.answerD: Allow you to look at road signs.
questions.explanation: Allowing a cushion of space around your motorcycle at all times will help ensure that you will have time to react if another driver makes a mistake. You will need the space to maneuver safely.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of an accident, you should:
questions.answerA: Only ride in the afternoon.
questions.answerB: Follow the vehicle in front of you as closely as possible.
questions.answerC: Not look ahead and focus only on your controls.
questions.answerD: Communicate your intentions to other drivers.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: How often should a motorcycle operator check their mirrors?
questions.answerA: Never
questions.answerB: Occasionally
questions.answerC: Frequently
questions.answerD: More often than the amount time spent looking ahead
questions.explanation: It is recommended that you frequently check your mirrors to be aware of potential hazards behind you.

questions.question: One of the benefits of performing regular maintenance on your motorcycle is that:
questions.answerA: The motorcycle will ride well for a long period of time.
questions.answerB: The maintenance check will take a lot of time.
questions.answerC: Maintenance will be costly.
questions.answerD: Maintenance checks can often prevent parking tickets.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle will continue to ride like new if it is properly maintained and routine inspections become a part of its regular maintenance cycle.

questions.question: If the throttle is stuck, you should:
questions.answerA: Jump off the motorcycle.
questions.answerB: Apply the brakes.
questions.answerC: Twist the throttle back and forth several times.
questions.answerD: Not try to twist the throttle.
questions.explanation: If your throttle becomes stuck, try twisting it back and forth several times. If this does not free your throttle, immediately operate the engine cut-off switch and pull in the clutch at the same time.

questions.question: Reflective material on your helmet:
questions.answerA: Helps you to be seen.
questions.answerB: Is not allowed.
questions.answerC: Should only be used at night.
questions.answerD: Does not help you to be seen.
questions.explanation: Reflective material on a vest or on the sides of your helmet can make you more visible to other drivers and should be used both day and night.

questions.question: Many over-the-counter drugs:
questions.answerA: Increase the danger of riding.
questions.answerB: Decrease the danger of riding.
questions.answerC: Only affect your riding if you drink along with taking the medication.
questions.answerD: Have the same effect on everyone.
questions.explanation: Like alcohol, many other drugs (including prescription medications, over-the-counter medications, and illegal drugs) have side effects that may impair your ability to ride safely.

questions.question: How does the stopping distance for motorcycles compare to the stopping distance for cars?
questions.answerA: Cars need much longer to stop.
questions.answerB: Cars need a little longer to stop.
questions.answerC: Motorcycles need longer to stop.
questions.answerD: Both motorcycles and cars take about the same amount of time to stop.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, the stopping distances for motorcycles is nearly the same as it is for cars. However, slippery pavement makes quick stops especially difficult for motorcycle operators.

questions.question: If you find your motorcycle being chased by a dog, you should:
questions.answerA: Swerve around the animal.
questions.answerB: Stop until the animal loses interest.
questions.answerC: Ride alongside the animal.
questions.answerD: Approach the animal slowly, then speed up.
questions.explanation: If you are being chased by a dog, downshift and approach it slowly. Then, as you approach the dog, accelerate and leave it behind.

questions.question: To increase your chances of being seen at an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn your headlight off.
questions.answerB: Ride with your headlight on.
questions.answerC: Try to make eye contact with other drivers.
questions.answerD: Ride as closely as possible to the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: The single most important thing you can do to help others see you at an intersection is to ride with your headlight on. Your headlight should be on whenever your motorcycle is running.

questions.question: If drinking alcohol, you should:
questions.answerA: Decide if you are still fit to ride based on how you feel after you finish drinking.
questions.answerB: Set a limit beforehand so you can still safely ride.
questions.answerC: Not ride.
questions.answerD: Not be concerned about your riding abilities if you feel fine.
questions.explanation: The surest way to avoid the risks of riding under the influence of alcohol is to not ride after you have been drinking. Any amount of alcohol can impair your abilities.

questions.question: Several factors influence blood alcohol concentration (BAC). Which of the following does not play a role?
questions.answerA: The amount of alcohol consumed
questions.answerB: How fast a person drinks
questions.answerC: Body weight
questions.answerD: Height
questions.explanation: There are several major factors that can affect a person's blood alcohol concentration (BAC). A BAC is determined in part by the amount of alcohol someone has consumed, how fast they consumed the alcohol, and their body weight.

questions.question: When riding a motorcycle:
questions.answerA: It is a good idea to drag your feet.
questions.answerB: Your toes should be pointed downward.
questions.answerC: You should keep your feet firmly on the footrests.
questions.answerD: You should try to keep your feet away from the controls.
questions.explanation: To maintain proper balance, your feet should be placed firmly on the footrests and not dragged on the ground. Do not point your toes downward, as this may cause them to catch on the road. Keep your feet near the controls so you can reach them quickly, if needed.

questions.question: As you slow or stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Shift up through the gears.
questions.answerB: Shift down through the gears.
questions.answerC: Take the bike out of gear.
questions.answerD: Stay in the same gear.
questions.explanation: You should shift down through the gears with the clutch as you slow or stop. Stay in first gear while you are stopped so you can move quickly, if needed.

questions.question: To control a motorcycle properly, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit so you can use your arms to steer, not to hold yourself up.
questions.answerB: Sit far enough back on the seat that you can keep your arms straight.
questions.answerC: Keep your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.answerD: Drag your feet on the ground.
questions.explanation: When riding, sit so you are able use your arms to control the motorcycle rather than to hold yourself up. Your arms should be slightly bent when you are holding the handle grips. To help maintain your balance, keep your knees against the gas tank and your feet firmly on the footrests.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a possible cause of a wobble on your motorcycle?
questions.answerA: Incorrect tire pressure
questions.answerB: Improper loading
questions.answerC: Unsuitable accessories
questions.answerD: Uneven road
questions.explanation: Most wobbles can be traced to improper loading, unsuitable accessories, or incorrect tire pressure. Do not try to accelerate out of a wobble.

questions.question: On which of the following surfaces does a motorcycle have the best traction?
questions.answerA: Dry pavement
questions.answerB: Gravel
questions.answerC: Snow
questions.answerD: Leaves
questions.explanation: A number of surfaces can provide poor traction for tires. Wet pavement; roads covered in loose gravel or sand; muddy, snowy, or icy areas; painted lane markings; and metal covers and plates in the road can be more hazardous for a motorcyclist than dry pavement.

questions.question: When braking, you should:
questions.answerA: First apply the front brake, then the rear.
questions.answerB: First apply the rear brake, then the front.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes at the same time.
questions.answerD: Use brakes in any order.
questions.explanation: Both brakes should be used at the same time whenever you slow or stop.

questions.question: The best lane position:
questions.answerA: Is always the right portion of the lane.
questions.answerB: Is always the center portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Is always the left portion of the lane.
questions.answerD: Varies based on road, weather, and traffic conditions.
questions.explanation: There is no single lane position that is always best and no single lane position that should always be avoided. You should vary your lane position in response to changes in riding conditions.

questions.question: If you are riding behind a car, you should:
questions.answerA: Stay in a lane position that makes you visible to the driver.
questions.answerB: Always ride in the far left portion of the lane.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about your placement.
questions.answerD: Always ride in the far right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: When riding directly behind a car, it is usually safest to ride in the center portion of your lane. If you are riding in the center of the lane, you are most likely to be visible in the rearview mirror of the vehicle ahead. Most drivers check their rearview mirror more frequently than they check their side mirrors.

questions.question: When carrying a passenger or cargo:
questions.answerA: It may take less time to accelerate, but more time to stop.
questions.answerB: It may take more time to accelerate and stop.
questions.answerC: It may take more time to accelerate, but less time to stop.
questions.answerD: It may take less time to accelerate and stop.
questions.explanation: Because of the additional weight added by cargo or a passenger, motorcycles may take longer to accelerate and stop than they would if only transporting the operator.

questions.question: All of the following will lessen your chances of being involved in an accident, except:
questions.answerA: Remaining alert.
questions.answerB: Identifying hazards and prioritizing risks.
questions.answerC: Riding without a headlight.
questions.answerD: Maintaining a space cushion.
questions.explanation: To reduce your risk of being involved in a crash, you should remain alert and ready to react to any hazard. Identify hazards and decide the order in which you need to address the hazards. Always use your headlight to make yourself more visible and maintain an adequate space cushion around your motorcycle at all times.

questions.question: Braking in a turn is:
questions.answerA: Easier than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerB: More difficult than braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: Done safely by using the front brake only.
questions.answerD: Done safely by using the rear brake only.
questions.explanation: Braking in a turn is not as easy as braking on a straightaway. It is possible to use both brakes to brake in a turn, but the operator must know the proper technique and exercise great care.

questions.question: When riding, the best sitting position:
questions.answerA: Requires your arms be used to hold you up.
questions.answerB: Allows you to easily reach the controls.
questions.answerC: Keeps your arms straight when reaching the handle grips.
questions.answerD: Keeps your knees away from the gas tank.
questions.explanation: When riding, you should be seated in a posture that allows you to use your arms to steer rather than to hold yourself up. You should not have to stretch to reach the handgrips and your arms should be slightly bent when holding them. You should keep your knees against the gas tank to maintain your balance.

questions.question: A good way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Ignore them.
questions.answerC: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerD: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.explanation: The best way to handle a tailgater is to change lanes and let them pass you. Speeding up may cause them to tailgate you at a higher speed, only increasing the danger.

questions.question: To increase your visibility, you should:
questions.answerA: Turn off your headlight during the day.
questions.answerB: Wear dark clothes.
questions.answerC: Keep your headlight on at all times.
questions.answerD: Ride in the right portion of the lane.
questions.explanation: Strategies for making yourself more visible include wearing brightly-colored and reflective clothing, keeping your headlight on at all times, and varying your lane position as conditions demand.

questions.question: Each traffic lane gives the motorcyclist how many paths of travel?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: Each traffic lane provides three paths of travel for motorcyclists: the left, center, and right portions of the lane.

questions.question: Who should set the pace in a group of riders?
questions.answerA: The leader
questions.answerB: The riders just behind the leader
questions.answerC: The rider in back
questions.answerD: The oldest rider
questions.explanation: The last rider in a group of motorcyclists should set the pace of travel. Having the last rider set the pace will ensure that no riders are left behind.

questions.question: The front brake is:
questions.answerA: Safe, if used properly.
questions.answerB: Safe, even if used improperly.
questions.answerC: Only to be used if the rear brake fails.
questions.answerD: Not to be used regularly.
questions.explanation: The front brake is safe to use as long as it is used properly. The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake, providing at least three-fourths of the total stopping power.

questions.question: If braking in a curve:
questions.answerA: Only use the front brake.
questions.answerB: It will be the same as braking on a straightaway.
questions.answerC: You will have more traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.answerD: You may have less traction as you lean into the curve.
questions.explanation: It is possible to use both brakes while turning, but it must be done with great care. Some of the tires' usual traction is being used to make the turn while the motorcycle is leaning, so less traction is available for stopping.

questions.question: You should check your tires for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Air pressure.
questions.answerB: Tread.
questions.answerC: General wear.
questions.answerD: Flexibility.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-ride inspection of your motorcycle, you should check the air pressure, general wear, and tread of your tires.

questions.question: If you are riding in traffic when a small animal enters your lane, you should:
questions.answerA: Do whatever you can, including swerving into other lanes, to avoid hitting the animal.
questions.answerB: Switch lanes as quickly as possible.
questions.answerC: Stay in your lane.
questions.answerD: Flash your lights to try to scare the animal.
questions.explanation: Do everything you safely can to avoid hitting an animal in the road. If you are in traffic, however, you should remain in your lane. Swerving into another lane of traffic to avoid hitting an animal can cause you to collide with another driver. Hitting something small is less dangerous than hitting something big.

questions.question: A pre-ride inspection should be done:
questions.answerA: Before every ride.
questions.answerB: Once a week.
questions.answerC: Once a month.
questions.answerD: Once a season.
questions.explanation: To prevent any dangerous situations caused by technical issues, you should perform a thorough inspection of your motorcycle before every ride. Compared to a car, small technical problems can have more serious consequences on a motorcycle.

questions.question: Your primary source for information about your motorcycle should be:
questions.answerA: The owner’s manual.
questions.answerB: A book about motorcycles.
questions.answerC: A former owner.
questions.answerD: Someone knowledgeable about motorcycles.
questions.explanation: Your owner's manual should be your primary source for information about your specific motorcycle. Your manual will include information about the motorcycle's specifications, operation, and suggested maintenance.

questions.question: When being followed too closely by another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Speed up.
questions.answerB: Move onto the shoulder.
questions.answerC: Allow the other driver to pass you.
questions.answerD: Exit the roadway.
questions.explanation: The best way to deal with a tailgater is to get them ahead of you. If you can do so safely, change lanes and let them pass. Speeding up may only increase the danger by encouraging them to continue tailgating you at a higher speed.

questions.question: Drivers on an entrance ramp may not see you on the highway. What should you do to help an entering driver merge safely?
questions.answerA: Stay in your lane, as it is not your responsibility to be seen.
questions.answerB: Change to a lane away from the entrance ramp, if possible.
questions.answerC: Move to the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Weave within your lane to be more obvious to the entering driver.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision, always allow merging vehicles plenty of space to safely enter traffic. Change lanes away from the entrance ramp if there is room to do so safely. If there isn't another lane available, adjust your speed to open up space for the merging driver.

questions.question: For routine braking:
questions.answerA: You should only use the front brake.
questions.answerB: You should only use the rear brake.
questions.answerC: You should alternate between the front and rear brakes to maximize the life of the brakes.
questions.answerD: You should always use both the front and rear brakes at the same time.
questions.explanation: Always use both brakes every time that you slow or stop.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a way to prevent a friend from driving while intoxicated?
questions.answerA: Arrange a safe ride home for them.
questions.answerB: Get them involved in activities to slow their drinking and keep them busy while they sober up.
questions.answerC: Make them wait 15 minutes after their last drink before driving.
questions.answerD: Get other friends involved in stopping your friend from driving.
questions.explanation: To prevent someone from drinking and driving, it is a good idea to arrange an alternative way for them to get home, involve them in other activities to slow the pace of their drinking, use any available excuse to keep them from leaving, and recruit friends to help apply peer pressure.

questions.question: When consumed together, the effects of alcohol and drugs:
questions.answerA: Can be more pronounced than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerB: Are less dangerous than when either is consumed alone.
questions.answerC: Are usually minimal.
questions.answerD: Often balance out.
questions.explanation: Many drugs, including prescription and over-the-counter medications, can impair your ability to ride safely. Some medications become even more dangerous when combined with alcohol.

questions.question: The center portion of a lane often contains an oily strip. This strip:
questions.answerA: Is not safe for motorcyclists at any time.
questions.answerB: Is usually safe for motorcyclists, unless it is raining.
questions.answerC: Should always be avoided since other parts of the lane do not have the oily strip.
questions.answerD: Adds to traction for most motorcycle tires.
questions.explanation: Oily drippings from cars collect in a strip in the center of a traffic lane. Unless the road is wet, this area will generally still provide enough traction for motorcyclists to ride safely. Because the strip is usually no more than two feet wide, it is often possible to ride to one side of the strip and still be in the center portion of the lane.

questions.question: Riding alongside a car:
questions.answerA: Is encouraged.
questions.answerB: Can place you in a blind spot.
questions.answerC: Is not an issue unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Can make driving easier for the other motorist.
questions.explanation: Riding directly alongside another vehicle is dangerous because it may place you in the driver's blind spot. Additionally, the vehicle will block your path of escape.

questions.question: Which fabric provides the most protection when worn by motorcyclists?
questions.answerA: Leather
questions.answerB: Denim
questions.answerC: Polyester
questions.answerD: Wool
questions.explanation: Leather jackets and pants provide the greatest level of protection when riding.

questions.question: The front brake:
questions.answerA: Provides less than half of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerB: Provides about 70 percent of a motorcycle's braking power.
questions.answerC: Should not be used unless the roadway is wet.
questions.answerD: Should be the only brake you use.
questions.explanation: The front brake is much more powerful than the rear one and provides at least 70 percent of a motorcycle's total stopping power. Use both brakes every time you slow or stop.

questions.question: It is best to not ride directly alongside another vehicle because:
questions.answerA: You may be riding in its blind spot.
questions.answerB: It is distracting to have a vehicle next to you.
questions.answerC: Other drivers may want to use the lane.
questions.answerD: It would be difficult to see what is happening behind you.
questions.explanation: It is dangerous to ride directly alongside a vehicle in another lane because you may be in the vehicle's blind spot and the driver will have no way of knowing you are there. It can also be dangerous because the vehicle may block your path of escape if another hazard arises.

questions.question: When you have mounted your motorcycle, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Make sure the mirrors are clean.
questions.answerB: Make sure the horn works.
questions.answerC: Close the fuel supply valve.
questions.answerD: Make sure the clutch works smoothly.
questions.explanation: After mounting your motorcycle, you should make sure the clutch, throttle, horn, and brakes all work properly. Clean and adjust the mirrors and make sure that the fuel supply valve is open.

questions.question: Compared to riding during the day, a motorcycle operator who is riding at night should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Ride more slowly.
questions.answerB: Allow more space between their motorcycle and other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Use their high beam whenever possible.
questions.answerD: Tailgate other vehicles.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of a collision when riding at night, be sure to reduce your speed and increase your following distance. Use the headlights of vehicles ahead of you to see farther down the road. You should always be flexible about your lane position, especially when riding at night.

questions.question: If in a no passing zone:
questions.answerA: A motorcycle may still pass another vehicle.
questions.answerB: A motorcycle is not allowed to pass another vehicle.
questions.answerC: A motorcycle may pass another vehicle if the pass can be completed before another vehicle approaches.
questions.answerD: A motorcycle may pass on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: Passing is prohibited in no passing zones. It is also prohibited to pass by riding off of the main-traveled portion of a roadway.

questions.question: To prevent getting fatigued on a long ride, you should do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Dress warmly.
questions.answerB: Limit the distance traveled in a day.
questions.answerC: Take frequent rest breaks.
questions.answerD: Take artificial stimulants.
questions.explanation: To reduce the danger of fatigue when riding, dress to protect yourself against tiring weather conditions, such as wind and rain. Limit yourself to no more than about six hours of riding per day and stop for a break at least once every two hours. Avoid taking artificial stimulants since you may experience extreme fatigue when they start to wear off.

questions.question: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, how many are caused by the driver failing to properly yield the right-of-way to the rider?
questions.answerA: About 10 percent
questions.answerB: About 25 percent
questions.answerC: Over 50 percent
questions.answerD: About 90 percent
questions.explanation: Of the crashes involving both a motorcycle and a car, more than half are caused by the driver failing to properly yield right-of-way to the rider.

questions.question: When approaching an intersection, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers see you, especially if they make eye contact.
questions.answerB: Never assume other drivers see you.
questions.answerC: Stay focused on moving through the intersection.
questions.answerD: Speed up to make others notice you.
questions.explanation: Never assume that other drivers see you, even if they make eye contact with you. It is not uncommon for drivers to look directly at a motorcyclist and still fail to notice them. Always reduce your speed when approaching an intersection.

questions.question: When entering a curve, a group should:
questions.answerA: Ride in a single-file formation.
questions.answerB: Ride in a staggered formation.
questions.answerC: Ride in pairs.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: While riding in a staggered formation is usually best, a group should switch into a single-file formation when turning, taking curves, or entering or exiting a highway.

questions.question: When riding in a group, inexperienced riders should position themselves:
questions.answerA: In the front of the group.
questions.answerB: Just behind the leader.
questions.answerC: Close to the back of the group.
questions.answerD: At the tail end of the group.
questions.explanation: In a group of motorcyclists, less experienced riders should be positioned toward the front, just behind the leader. This ensures that they will not have to chase after the rest of the group. This positioning also allows them to be watched from behind by more experienced riders.

questions.question: What should you do to maintain proper control of your motorcycle while turning?
questions.answerA: Increase your speed before entering the turn.
questions.answerB: Keep the motorcycle from leaning.
questions.answerC: Look through the turn to anticipate the best course of action.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop before entering the turn.
questions.explanation: To maintain directional control through a turn, you should look through the turn by turning only your head. Slow down before turning and lean your motorcycle in the appropriate direction.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Protects more than just your eyes.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield helps protect your entire face, including your eyes. Goggles can protect your eyes, but not the rest of your face. A windshield is not an adequate substitute for either.

questions.question: When passing another vehicle:
questions.answerA: You may ride on the shoulder.
questions.answerB: You may complete the pass in a no passing zone.
questions.answerC: You must start and complete the pass within a passing zone.
questions.answerD: You should sound your horn to get the other driver to slow down.
questions.explanation: All passing maneuvers must be completed within the posted speed limits and only in areas where passing is safe and legal.

questions.question: A proper lane position can help you do all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Avoid other drivers' blindspots.
questions.answerB: Increase your ability to see and be seen.
questions.answerC: Go faster.
questions.answerD: Set up for turns.
questions.explanation: Your lane position affects a number of factors that are important to your safety on the road. Among other things, your position should help you increase your ability to see and be seen, avoid other drivers' blind spots, and set you up for any turns you plan to make.

questions.question: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should:
questions.answerA: Do one, then the other.
questions.answerB: Do both at the same time.
questions.answerC: Always apply the brakes first, then swerve.
questions.answerD: Try instead to use only the brakes.
questions.explanation: If you must brake and swerve to avoid a hazard, you should perform both actions separately. Brake then swerve, or swerve then brake. Do not do both at the same time.

questions.question: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield:
questions.answerA: Is not necessary if you have a windshield.
questions.answerB: Only protects your eyes.
questions.answerC: Helps protect your whole face.
questions.answerD: Does not protect your face as well as goggles.
questions.explanation: A plastic, shatter-resistant face shield can help protect your whole face in a crash. While goggles can protect your eyes, they won't protect the rest of your face. A windshield is not a substitute for a face shield or goggles.

questions.question: To stop quickly, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Use the rear brake firmly while gradually increasing the braking pressure of the front brake.
questions.explanation: To stop quickly, apply both brakes at the same time.

questions.question: When passing parked cars, which part of the lane should you usually use?
questions.answerA: The left portion of the lane
questions.answerB: The center portion of the lane
questions.answerC: The right portion of the lane
questions.answerD: Either the left or right portion of the lane
questions.explanation: When passing a row of parked cars, it is often safest to ride in the left portion of your lane. Riding in the left portion will keep you farthest from any opening car doors, people stepping out from between cars, and cars pulling out of parking spaces.

questions.question: The best way to handle tailgaters is to:
questions.answerA: Change lanes and let them pass.
questions.answerB: Use your horn and make obscene gestures.
questions.answerC: Speed up to put distance between you and the tailgater.
questions.answerD: Come to a complete stop.
questions.explanation: If possible, change lanes and let a tailgater pass your vehicle. Speeding up may result in the driver continuing to tailgate you at a higher speed, thereby increasing the danger.

questions.question: Which of the following will best protect your eyes from wind?
questions.answerA: Eyeglasses
questions.answerB: Sunglasses
questions.answerC: A windshield
questions.answerD: Goggles
questions.explanation: Goggles and face shields will help protect your eyes from wind. Most windshields, as well as eyeglasses or sunglasses, will not.

questions.question: If road conditions require a longer stopping distance than normal, you should:
questions.answerA: Decrease your usual following distance.
questions.answerB: Increase your usual following distance.
questions.answerC: Travel on the shoulder.
questions.answerD: Ask someone else to operate your motorcycle.
questions.explanation: An increased following distance is needed if your motorcycle will take longer than normal to stop. If the pavement is slippery, if you cannot see through the vehicle ahead of you, or if traffic is heavy and another driver may try to squeeze in front of you, open up to a minimum three-second following distance.

questions.question: To carry a passenger, you may need to adjust all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Tire pressure.
questions.answerB: Mirror positions.
questions.answerC: Headlight position.
questions.answerD: Brake light position.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle carrying a passenger will sit differently than usual due to the additional weight. You may need to adjust the tire pressure, suspension, shocks, headlight, and mirrors to compensate for the shift.

questions.question: If you are transporting a passenger, they should:
questions.answerA: Lean as you lean.
questions.answerB: Hold onto the motorcycle seat.
questions.answerC: Sit as far back as possible.
questions.answerD: Never hold onto you.
questions.explanation: A passenger should lean with the operator through turns and curves. They should sit as far forward as possible, without hindering the operator's control of the motorcycle, and hold onto passenger handholds or the operator's waist, hips, or belt.

questions.question: How much of a motorcycle's total braking power can the front brake supply?
questions.answerA: About 10 percent
questions.answerB: About 25 percent
questions.answerC: About 50 percent
questions.answerD: About 70 percent
questions.explanation: The front brake of a motorcycle is more powerful than the rear brake. It supplies at least three-quarters of the motorcycle's total stopping power.

questions.question: You should choose the lane position that can:
questions.answerA: Minimize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerB: Maximize your space cushion and allow you to be seen by others.
questions.answerC: Maximize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow others to pass you.
questions.answerD: Minimize your potential for encountering road hazards and allow you to closely follow another vehicle.
questions.explanation: A properly chosen lane position should provide a number of benefits, including an increased ability to see others and to be seen. It should help you avoid wind blasts, other drivers' blind spots, and surface hazards. Your lane position should discourage other drivers from trying to share your lane and provide you with an escape route, should a hazard arise. Choose a lane position that maximizes your space cushion.

questions.question: When riding in fog, you should:
questions.answerA: Use your high beam headlight.
questions.answerB: Use your low beam headlight.
questions.answerC: Use no lights.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the low and high beams.
questions.explanation: You should use your low beam headlight when riding in foggy conditions. Do not use your high beams when riding near other vehicles.

questions.question: You should do all of the following to lesson your chances of being in a crash, except:
questions.answerA: Be visible by wearing proper clothing and using your headlight.
questions.answerB: Communicate your intentions by using your turn signals and brake light.
questions.answerC: Search for hazards in your path.
questions.answerD: Hope the other drivers see you.
questions.explanation: To minimize your risk of a crash, ensure that you are visible to other drivers, communicating your intentions to other drivers, and maintaining a cushion of space around you. You should search for, identify, and separate hazards. Be prepared to react to anything that happens.

questions.question: A helmeted rider is _______ more likely to survive a crash than a rider not wearing a helmet.
questions.answerA: Two times
questions.answerB: Three times
questions.answerC: Six times
questions.answerD: 20 times
questions.explanation: No matter the speed, riders who are not wearing helmets are three times more likely to die from head injuries than riders who are wearing helmets at the time of a crash.

questions.question: Generally, the body eliminates how many alcoholic drinks per hour?
questions.answerA: One
questions.answerB: Two
questions.answerC: Three
questions.answerD: Four
questions.explanation: On average, a person's body can eliminate the alcohol content of about one drink per hour. The amount of time required to lower a person's blood alcohol content (BAC) can vary, so it is safest not to operate any motor vehicle after consuming any amount of alcohol.

questions.question: To lessen your chances of being involved in a crash, you should:
questions.answerA: Be visible to other drivers.
questions.answerB: Keep your intentions unknown from other drivers.
questions.answerC: Always stay within a foot of another vehicle.
questions.answerD: Ride on the shoulder.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of being involved in a crash, you should always ensure that you are visible to others. Communicate your intentions through proper use of your signals, brake light, and lane position. Maintain a space cushion around your motorcycle and consistently scan the road ahead of, behind, and next to your vehicle.

questions.question: It is important to flash your brake light when:
questions.answerA: Approaching a police officer.
questions.answerB: Someone is following too closely.
questions.answerC: There is a stop sign ahead.
questions.answerD: Your signals are not working.
questions.explanation: It is a good idea to flash your brake light before slowing if someone is following you too closely. The other driver may be focused on you and be unaware of the upcoming hazard that is causing you to slow down. It is also important to flash your brake light if you are about to slow down in a place where other drivers might not expect you to do so.

questions.question: When riding under ideal conditions, you should maintain a minimum following distance of:
questions.answerA: One second.
questions.answerB: Two seconds.
questions.answerC: Three seconds.
questions.answerD: Four seconds.
questions.explanation: Under normal conditions, you should maintain a following distance of at least two seconds. Increase your following distance any time conditions are less than perfect.

questions.question: If a friend has had too much to drink and wants to ride their motorcycle, you should:
questions.answerA: Let them.
questions.answerB: Encourage them to take roads that are not crowded.
questions.answerC: Not get involved.
questions.answerD: Take their keys.
questions.explanation: Never let someone ride if they have had too much to drink. Do whatever you can to prevent them from riding, including taking their keys, if necessary. Arrange an alternative way for them to get home.

questions.question: When making normal stops, you should:
questions.answerA: Use only the rear brake.
questions.answerB: Use only the front brake.
questions.answerC: Use both the front and rear brakes.
questions.answerD: Alternate between the front and rear brakes.
questions.explanation: Make it a habit to always use both brakes when slowing or stopping, even for normal, non-emergency stops.

questions.question: When stopped behind another vehicle, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close as possible to the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Maintain a space cushion between your motorcycle and the other vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not use your rearview mirrors to monitor traffic behind you.
questions.answerD: Look for opportunities to squeeze through the stopped traffic.
questions.explanation: You should stay well behind the vehicle in front of you, even when you are both stopped. This will give you room to escape if the vehicle backs up unexpectedly or if another vehicle approaches too quickly from behind.

questions.question: A motorcycle “fits” you if:
questions.answerA: You are able to touch your feet to the ground while seated.
questions.answerB: You are able to reach the controls by stretching.
questions.answerC: The handlebars go over your head.
questions.answerD: Your feet are unable to rest on the foot pegs.
questions.explanation: A motorcycle fits you properly if your feet can reach the ground while you are seated on the motorcycle. It should be easy for you to reach and operate the controls.

questions.question: Which of the following is a good color to wear to be seen?
questions.answerA: Orange
questions.answerB: Black
questions.answerC: Brown
questions.answerD: Deep blue
questions.explanation: Orange, red, yellow, or green clothing can make you easier to see while riding a motorcycle. Wear brightly-colored clothing no matter what time of day you are riding.

questions.question: When riding on a slippery surface, you should not:
questions.answerA: Reduce your speed.
questions.answerB: Avoid sudden moves.
questions.answerC: Use both brakes.
questions.answerD: Brake quickly.
questions.explanation: To safely ride on a slippery surface, you should reduce your speed, avoid making sudden movements, and use both brakes if you need to brake.

questions.question: As an operator, you should prepare a passenger to ride by instructing them to do each of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Get on the motorcycle after the engine has been started.
questions.answerB: Sit as far forward as possible.
questions.answerC: Maintain a large space between themselves and you.
questions.answerD: Keep their legs away from the muffler and chains.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a ride, you should ask your passenger to mount the motorcycle only after the engine has been started. They should sit as far forward as they can without crowding you and hold onto the motorcycle's passenger handholds or onto your waist, hips, or belt. They should keep their legs away from the muffler, chains, and other moving parts.
